column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Teaching English
#Text=One way to travel — or to pay for your travels — is to get a job overseas teaching English .
#Text=If you want to spend several years in a destination , this is a popular way to earn a living .
#Text=Jobs worth considering as a long-term prospect — or even as a career — are widely available .
#Text=They generally require qualifications and experience ; see Certificates below .
#Text=In many such positions , the benefits include airfare and housing , though there is great variation from country to country and by type of institution .
#Text=Other jobs might do to supplement a backpacker 's income , or even let you live somewhere interesting for a year .
#Text=For some of these jobs , especially in remote areas , anyone who looks foreign and speaks some English can get work .
#Text=Again , details vary greatly .
#Text=Speaking the local language is not generally required for the job itself , though it may be quite useful in beginner classes and will make your stay far easier and more pleasant in other ways .
#Text=Jargon
#Text=The students are learning ESL ( English as a Second Language ) or EFL ( English as a Foreign Language ) or ESOL ( English for Speakers of Other Languages ) .

#Text=Some people make much of the distinction between ESL ( in a English-speaking country so TV , shops and so on all help you learn ) and EFL ( English is almost never used except in class ) , but others treat the terms as interchangeable .
#Text=For the teacher , add a T for Teaching to get TESL , TEFL or TESOL , or just call the field ELT ( English Language Teaching ) .
#Text=A trend in the last few decades is to do a lot of ESP ( English for Specific Purposes ) , designing custom courses depending on what the learners need to use the language for .
#Text=One branch of this is EAP ( English for Academic Purposes ) , preparing students for study abroad .
#Text=A major part of the ESP approach is needs analysis , figuring out how your students will use the language .
#Text=Consider a company somewhere that exports products to English-speaking countries .
#Text=The engineers might just need to read manuals and product specifications in English ; they might never hear , speak or write it .
#Text=Marketers might need to read the quite different language of orders and contracts , and to both read and write emails in much less formal language .
#Text=Some of them might also need to talk with customers .
#Text=Executives might need to handle complex negotiations in English — a task that requires not only excellent spoken English but also business skills and an awareness of cultural differences .
#Text=Ideally , each of these groups would get an almost completely different English course .
#Text=In some situations , needs analysis is a formal process and courses are written to order for specific groups .
#Text=Often , however , the teacher just does an informal analysis and finds or invents exercises to suit a class .
#Text=Tests

#Text=A good score on an English test is almost always required for students whose native language is not English to study at a university that uses English ( sometimes even when the university has a different primary language ) .
#Text=Tests may also be required for visas in some countries or for some jobs .
#Text=The widely-used tests have their own acronyms :
#Text=TOEFL
#Text=, for admission to US universities
#Text=IELTS
#Text=, for British , Irish , Canadian , Australian and NZ universities
#Text=TOEIC
#Text=, a business
#Text=English test from the TOEFL people
#Text=BULATS
#Text=, a business
#Text=English test from the IELTS people
#Text=BEC
#Text=, business English Certificates from Cambridge ( three exams at different levels )
#Text=CPE
#Text=, also from Cambridge : their highest level exam .
#Text=Teachers abroad may supplement their income by serving as examiners or markers
#Text=for these tests , though both the demand and the pay rates for this vary considerably from place to place , and they are different for each test .
#Text=In China a typical teacher can roughly double his or her income by working as an IELTS examiner a few weekends a month .

#Text=Requirements are stiff , though — IELTS 9 ( native speaker level ) English , a TEFL certificate ( CELTA or Trinity OK , anything else subject to discussion ) and three years classroom teaching experience with adult students ( neither teaching kids nor online teaching counts ) .
#Text=That gets you into examiner training ; there is a fee for the course and any travel involved is at your expense .
#Text=You then need to pass a stiff test , and re-take it every two years , to actually get the work .
#Text=Some ESL students may also need or want to take other tests to get into foreign universities ; these are not ESL tests , but admission tests designed for native English speakers .
#Text=The main ones are :
#Text=SAT
#Text=and ACT for undergraduate admissions
#Text=GRE
#Text=for most graduate programs , with both a general test and specific tests for different fields .
#Text=For more on these tests and discussion of others , see Studying abroad .
#Text=The work
#Text=Teaching ESL ( or any other language ) has much in common with any other teaching , but also has its own unique challenges .

#Text=Among other things , it needs some understanding of how language works , quite a bit of patience , and considerable showmanship since non-verbal techniques such as gesture and facial expressions are often needed to scaffold the weaker linguistic understanding of the learner .

#Text=Teaching English as a second language is significantly different than teaching English literature and composition to a class of ( mostly ) native speakers , though of course there is overlap as well .
#Text=For one thing , an ESL teacher has to deal with a wider range of problems , notably pronunciation difficulties and spoken usage questions , such as when " How are you ?

column1: #Text=" Also , in any language even intelligent adult second language learners make grammar errors on things any eight-year-old native speaker gets 100 % right ; an ESL teacher has to teach and correct those .
